text: Technology can help solve the
most important challenges for the Earth,
including climate change,
and building more sustainable cities.

Growing up on a farm, I saw the
problem from the inside.

I saw how the farm was
 not organised digitally.
Everything was on paper

so accessing every piece
of information took time.
Imagine we have an app

that connects everything 
around the farm.

I saw that we both
collect data and

use these technologies to 
make positive impacts.

Maybe you can tell me what
you do in the cities.

Cities today are at the
frontier of climate change
because a large part of consumption,
a large part of emissions, are made in cities.

The issue we addressed is how
to help these cities become more sustainable,

how to make them more resilient, 
and the answer,

Mayors, city planners, councillors
never knew where to get the data
and how to make decisions.
So that was kind of our vision.

In terms of sustainability impact, 
how do you help farmers

on this vision of a
more sustainable, resilient world?
We work on two pieces of data.

On the operational side we
work with farms to measure

the reductions, on
the efficiency we can achieve.

For example, when using water for
irrigation, we measure how much water is
saved with the same production.

We work on fertiliser reduction, 
on reducing the time we use the machines.

Considering that we take the
telemetry of the tractors in real time,

we can process them
and are able to give advice.

So for us the impact is pure
operational efficiency.

On the other hand, we have the environmental impact part
where we measure the reduction of

carbon footprint, all
water management KPIs then

we can measure all the impact
on the environment.
So there are these two big groups.

And you, Gaetano, how do you
measure the impact you have on society,
on cities, and also on the environment?

Yes, we now address the issue of impact
both in the urban sphere and the economy

as it is becoming increasingly important
not only for ESG issues but also for
all the necessary reporting.

For example, we are working with
Milan on a plan to deal with air pollution.

Milan needs to plant a huge number
of trees and clearly identify

a spot where they can plant new
trees or intervene with
nature-based solutions:

interventions with solutions
based on nature.

It is important on the one hand to
know the presence of green public spaces,
but also the presence of private greenery.

Knowing the risks, for example,
temperature, urban heat islands,
land use level,

then integrate this data
with the city's open data.

So, where hospitals are, where schools are, 
where public offices are, where cycle paths are.

And then using our technology
in Milan, it locates hotspots

with greater risk where they can
carry out nature-based interventions.
In what way has

AWS helped you support
this innovative idea of
digitisation of agriculture?

Imagine we have an app that
connects everything around the farm
Machinery, sensors, satellites and so on.

So every day we digest a
lot of data that has to
be stored, processed.

So on the one hand we saw
the scalability part.
So storage, data processing.

On the other hand, in recent years we have
worked so much on the value added that

we came up with the whole AI part.
So we process data

that is extremely complex from
different sources and we extrapolate the

simple solution for the farmer.
This is what we do with all the technology.
We were basically born with AWS

I mean, we never had a
server in our office because we do a

job that requires a lot
of computational capacity.

customer installations.

We also hope to get to those numbers and
have an architecture that can follow
this scalability of the business.

Today we do a lot of work throughout
South America. So from Brazil to Chile to

Peru, these countries are extremely
interesting to us, as we are

on the other side of the globe
in India, which has a very large
population of farmers.

Considering that in Europe we have 14 million
farmers, in India, there are 140 million.

So another scale and certainly a very
interesting market with many challenges

However, this is really where
we can see how the scale up works.

We want to look at the United States as
well as South America, which are

two very interesting markets,
but also Asia.
